'''Andrew R. Jassy''' (born January 13, 1968)<ref>{{Cite news |last=Long |first=Katherine Anne |date=February 6, 2021 |title=As incoming Amazon CEO Andy Jassy steps into the limelight, a portrait of a leader much like Jeff Bezos emerges |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/business/amazon/as-incoming-amazon-ceo-andy-jassy-steps-into-the-limelight-a-portrait-of-a-leader-much-like-jeff-bezos-emerges/ |work=The Seattle Times |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240324013006/https://www.seattletimes.com/business/amazon/as-incoming-amazon-ceo-andy-jassy-steps-into-the-limelight-a-portrait-of-a-leader-much-like-jeff-bezos-emerges/ |archive-date=March 24, 2024 |url-status=live}}</ref> is an American business executive who is the president and chief executive officer of [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]]. Before being appointed by [[Jeff Bezos]] and the Amazon board during the fourth quarter of 2020,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Weise |first1=Karen |title=Jeff Bezos to Step Down as Amazon C.E.O. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/02/technology/jeff-bezos-amazon.html |work=The New York Times |date=2 February 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Haselton |first1=Todd |title=Jeff Bezos to step down as Amazon CEO, Andy Jassy to take over in Q3 |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/02/jeff-bezos-to-step-down-as-amazon-ceo-andy-jassy-to-take-over-in-q3.html |work=CNBC |date=2 February 2021 |language=en}}</ref> Jassy had been the SVP and CEO of [[Amazon Web Services]] from 2003 to 2021.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Andy Jassy will be the next CEO of Amazon. Insiders dish on what it's like to work for Jeff Bezos' successor who built AWS into a $40 billion business |archive-url=https://archive.today/20210202220756/https://www.businessinsider.com/andy-jassy-amazon-web-services-ceo-2021-1 |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/andy-jassy-amazon-web-services-ceo-2021-1?IR=T |archive-date=February 2, 2021 |date=31 Jan 2021 |publisher=[[Business Insider]] |last1=Eugene |first1=Kim |first2=Ashley |last2=Stewart |access-date=3 Feb 2021 |url-status=live }}</ref>

==Early life and education==
Jassy is the son of Margery and Everett L. Jassy of [[Scarsdale, New York]].<ref name="nytmar">{{Cite news|title=Elana Caplan And Andrew Jassy |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/24/style/elana-caplan-and-andrew-jassy.html |access-date=February 2, 2021|issn=0362-4331 |date=August 24, 1997 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20210203080100/https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/24/style/elana-caplan-and-andrew-jassy.html |archive-date=3 February 2021}}</ref> Of Jewish{{r|yworld}}<ref>{{Cite web|title=Amazon's next CEO Andy Jassy is Jewish|url=https://www.jta.org/quick-reads/amazons-next-ceo-andy-jassy-is-jewish|access-date=2021-02-05|website=Jewish Telegraphic Agency|date=February 4, 2021 |language=en-US}}</ref> [[Jasz people|Hungarian]] ancestry,<ref name=yworld>{{Cite news |title=Amazon's Next CEO Andy Jassy Is Jewish |url=https://www.theyeshivaworld.com/news/headlines-breaking-stories/1945868/amazons-next-ceo-andy-jassy-is-jewish.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20210215104523/https://www.theyeshivaworld.com/news/headlines-breaking-stories/1945868/amazons-next-ceo-andy-jassy-is-jewish.html |archive-date=15 February 2021 |date= February 7, 2021 |access-date=February 14, 2021 |website=The Yeshiva World News}}</ref> his father was a senior partner in the [[corporate law]] firm [[Dewey Ballantine]] in New York City, and chairman of the firm's management committee.{{r|nytmar}} Jassy grew up in [[Scarsdale, New York|Scarsdale]], and attended [[Scarsdale High School]],{{r|nytmar}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scarsdale10583.com/the-goods/4244-amazon-s-andy-jassy-86-to-be-interviewed-by-dr-hagerman-on-tuesday-at-8pm|title=Amazon's Andy Jassy '86 to be interviewed by Dr. Hagerman on Tuesday at 8pm|first=Adrienne|last=Fishman|date=September 11, 2014|website=scarsdale10583.com|access-date=October 12, 2017}}</ref> where he played varsity soccer and tennis.<ref name="wsj2">{{cite news |last1=Tilley |first1=Aaron |title=Amazon Primed Andy Jassy to Be CEO. Can He Keep What Jeff Bezos Built? |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/amazon-primed-andy-jassy-to-be-ceo-can-he-keep-what-jeff-bezos-built-11625218225 |access-date=12 July 2021 |work=Wall Street Journal |date=2 July 2021}}</ref>

Jassy graduated ''[[cum laude]]'' from [[Harvard College]] in government, where he was advertising manager of ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]'', before earning an MBA from [[Harvard Business School]]. In 1989, he wrote in ''The Crimson'' that the newspaper should continue to publish advertisements from [[Eastern Air Lines]], despite an ongoing [[labor dispute]] there.<ref>{{Cite web |title=No Eds in Ads {{!}} Opinion {{!}} The Harvard Crimson |url=https://www.thecrimson.com/article/1989/4/19/no-eds-in-ads-pbrbegardless-of/ |access-date=2022-04-14 |website=www.thecrimson.com}}</ref><ref name="Hook">{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/a515eb7a-d0ef-11e5-831d-09f7778e7377|title=Person of the Year: Amazon Web Services' Andy Jassy|first=Leslie|last=Hook|date=March 17, 2016|website=Financial Times|access-date=October 12, 2017|archive-url=https://archive.today/20210205200823/https://www.ft.com/content/a515eb7a-d0ef-11e5-831d-09f7778e7377 |archive-date=5 February 2021 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="bloomberg.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/people/15111610-andrew-r-jassy|title=Andrew Jassy, Amazon.Com Inc: Profile & Biography|author=|date=|website=Bloomberg|access-date=October 12, 2017}}</ref>

==Career==
Jassy worked for five years after graduation before entering his MBA program as a project manager for a [[Collectable|collectible]]s company, [[Danbury Mint|MBI]], and then he and an MBI colleague started a company and closed it down.<ref name="Hook" /><ref name="auto2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.hbs.edu/forum-for-growth-and-innovation/podcasts/disruptive-voice/Pages/podcast-details.aspx?episode=15834284|title=Podcast - Forum for Growth & Innovation - Harvard Business School|website=www.hbs.edu|archive-url=https://archive.today/20210204142729/https://www.hbs.edu/forum-for-growth-and-innovation/podcasts/disruptive-voice/Pages/podcast-details.aspx?episode=15834284|archive-date=February 4, 2021|access-date=February 3, 2021|url-status=live}}</ref>

Jassy joined Amazon as a marketing manager in 1997<ref name="wsj2"/> with several other Harvard MBA colleagues.<ref name="auto2"/><ref name="Hook" /> In 2003, he and [[Jeff Bezos]] came up with the idea to create the [[cloud computing]] platform that became known as [[Amazon Web Services]], which launched in 2006.<ref name="wsj1">{{cite news |last1=Tilley |first1=Aaron |title=Who Is Andy Jassy? Jeff Bezos Acolyte Moves From Cloud to Amazon CEO |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/who-is-andy-jassy-jeff-bezos-acolyte-moves-from-cloud-to-amazon-ceo-11612309443?mod=searchresults_pos6&page=1 |access-date=3 February 2021 |work=Wall Street Journal |date=2 February 2021}}</ref> Jassy headed it and its team of 57 people.<ref name="auto"/>

[[File:Andy Jassy in 2016.jpg|thumb|right|Jassy in 2016]]
In 2016, Jassy was named Person of the Year by the ''[[Financial Times]]''.<ref name="Hook" /> A month later, Jassy was promoted from senior vice president to chief executive officer of Amazon Web Services (AWS).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://venturebeat.com/2016/04/07/andy-jassy-is-finally-named-ceo-of-amazon-web-services/ |title=Andy Jassy is finally named CEO of Amazon Web Services |last1=Novet |first1=Jordan |date=7 Apr 2016 |publisher=[[VentureBeat]] |access-date=12 October 2017 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20210203123143/https://venturebeat.com/2016/04/07/andy-jassy-is-finally-named-ceo-of-amazon-web-services/ |archive-date=February 3, 2021 |url-status=live }}</ref>{{r|bloomberg.com}} That year Jassy earned $36.6 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/04/12/aws-ceo-andrew-jassys-2016-pay-hits-35-6-million.html|title=The most highly paid Amazon executive isn't the CEO — it's the head of cloud|first=Anita|last=Balakrishnan|date=April 12, 2017|publisher=CNBC|access-date=October 12, 2017}}</ref>

For his work as CEO of AWS, Jassy earned a base compensation of $175,000 in 2020, plus a [[restricted stock]] unit award of 4,023 shares (a value of $12,104,844.93 as of July 26, 2020<ref name="AMZNPrice">{{cite web | url = https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/AMZN?p=AMZN | title = Amazon.com, Inc. (AMZN) | access-date = July 26, 2020}}</ref>) of Amazon with [[vesting]] beginning in 2023. He also received a restricted stock unit award in April 2018 for 10,000 shares (a value of $30,089,100 as of July 26, 2020),<ref name="AMZNPrice"/> which vest 37.5% in 2021, 12.5% in 2022, 37.5% in 2023, and 12.5% in 2024.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://materials.proxyvote.com/Approved/023135/20200402/NPS_425478.PDF| title = Notice of 2020 Annual Meeting of Shareholders & Proxy Statement | date=May 22, 2020 | access-date = July 26, 2020 |ref=Page 55, 56, 57}}</ref> He was succeeded as CEO of AWS by Adam Selipsky.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2021-03-23 |title=AWS announces next CEO |url=https://www.aboutamazon.com/news/company-news/aws-announces-next-ceo |access-date=2024-03-27 |website=US About Amazon |language=en}}</ref>

In January 2021, Bezos designated Jassy his official successor as CEO;<ref>{{Cite web |date=November 23, 2021 |first=Avery |last=Hartmans |title=Jeff Bezos surprised Andy Jassy by picking him as Amazon CEO: VF |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/jeff-bezos-choosing-andy-jassy-surprised-amazon-ceo-2021-11 |access-date=2022-06-03 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US}}</ref> with the transition occurring on July 5, 2021.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Palmer |first1=Annie |title=first year after succeeding Bezos as Amazon CEO |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/07/05/andy-jassy-just-wrapped-up-a-rocky-first-year-after-as-amazon-ceo.html |website=CNBC |date=July 5, 2022 |access-date=8 April 2023}}</ref> As CEO of Amazon, Jassy received a ten year pay package totaling $212.7 million. The majority of the compensation package is in stock and vests over 10 years.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Thorbecke |first=Catherine |date=April 1, 2022 |title=Amazon CEO Andy Jassy's total compensation package topped $212 million |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2022/04/01/tech/andy-jassy-amazon-ceo-pay/index.html |access-date=April 4, 2022 |website=CNN International}}</ref>

In 2024, Andy Jassy continued to lead Amazon as CEO, emphasizing the company's focus on artificial intelligence (AI) and cloud computing. Jassy described AI as "the biggest change since the cloud and possibly the internet," predicting that every customer experience would be reinvented with AI.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-12-05 |title=Exclusive: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy reveals AWS' strategy for building the enterprise AI platform |url=https://siliconangle.com/2024/12/05/exclusive-amazon-ceo-andy-jassy-reveals-aws-strategy-building-enterprise-ai-platform/ |access-date=2024-12-25 |website=SiliconANGLE |language=en-US}}</ref>

Jassy's commitment to AI innovation was evident in Amazon's financial strategy. The company announced plans to spend more than $75 billion on capital expenditures in 2025, with most of that investment directed towards AWS and generative AI.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |last=Millward |first=Wade Tyler |title=Amazon Q3 2024 Earnings: CEO Jassy Says AI ‘Once In A Lifetime’ Opportunity |url=https://www.crn.com/news/cloud/2024/amazon-q3-2024-earnings-ceo-jassy-says-ai-once-in-a-lifetime-opportunity |access-date=2024-12-25 |website=www.crn.com}}</ref> Jassy described this as a "really unusually large, maybe once in a lifetime, type of opportunity".<ref name=":0" /> Amazon's overall financial performance under Jassy's leadership remained strong. In Q3 2024, the company reported revenue of $158.9 billion, an 11% increase year-over-year, with operating income surging by 56% to $17.4 billion.<ref name=":0" /><ref>https://finance.yahoo.com/news/amazon-com-third-quarter-2024-120304876.html</ref>

Customer satisfaction remained high during Jassy's tenure. In 2024, Amazon's customer satisfaction score was 83 out of 100 ACSI points, maintaining its position as one of the top-rated companies in the American Customer Satisfaction Index.<ref>{{Cite web |title=U.S. customer satisfaction with Amazon 2024 |url=https://www.statista.com/statistics/185788/us-customer-satisfaction-with-amazon/ |access-date=2024-12-25 |website=Statista |language=en}}</ref>

==Personal life==
In 1997, Jassy married Elana Rochelle Caplan, a fashion designer for [[Eddie Bauer]] and graduate of the [[Philadelphia College of Textiles and Science]], at a [[Loews Hotels|Loews Hotel]] in [[Santa Monica, California]].{{r|nytmar}}  Their wedding was officiated by New York reform Rabbi James Brandt, a cousin of Elana.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://meaww.com/who-is-elana-jassy-wife-of-andy-jassy-new-amazon-ceo-jeff-bezos-politcal-donation-travel-family |title=Meet Elana Rochelle Caplan, Amazon's next CEO Andy Jassy's fashion designer wife who loves traveling |archive-url=https://archive.today/20210205002707/https://meaww.com/who-is-elana-jassy-wife-of-andy-jassy-new-amazon-ceo-jeff-bezos-politcal-donation-travel-family |archive-date=5 February 2021 |website=meaww.com|date=February 3, 2021 }}</ref> Both their fathers were senior partners in law firm [[Dewey Ballantine]].{{r|nytmar}} Jassy and Caplan have two children.<ref name="fortune15">{{Cite news |title=How Andy Jassy helped Amazon own the cloud |url=https://fortune.com/2015/06/28/andy-jassy-amazon-web-services/ |archive-url=https://archive.today/20210203192009/https://fortune.com/2015/06/28/andy-jassy-amazon-web-services/ |date=28 Jun 2015 |archive-date=3 February 2021 |access-date=23 Feb 2021 |last1=Rao |first1=Leena |publisher=[[Fortune.com]]}}</ref>

They live in the [[Capitol Hill, Seattle|Capitol Hill]] neighborhood of [[Seattle]] in a 10,000-square-foot house bought in 2009 for $3.1 million.<ref name="montgomerysummit">{{cite web |title=Andy Jassy: Amazon Web Services (AWS) CEO |url=https://www.montgomerysummit.com/speakers/andy-jassy/ |archive-url=https://archive.today/20210223073917/https://www.montgomerysummit.com/speakers/andy-jassy/ |archive-date=23 February 2021 |website=montgomerysummit |access-date=2 February 2021}}</ref><ref name="auto3">{{Cite web |url=https://www.dirt.com/moguls/tech/amazon-andy-jassy-house-santa-monica-1203344910/ |title=Amazon Web Services CEO Andy Jassy Buys Prime Santa Monica Home|first1=James|last1=McClain|date=October 14, 2020 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20210223074027/https://www.dirt.com/moguls/tech/amazon-andy-jassy-house-santa-monica-1203344910/ |archive-date=23 February 2021}}</ref> In October 2020, it was reported that Jassy had bought a $6.7 million 5,500-square-foot house in Santa Monica.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/Who-is-Andy-Jassy-the-Amazon-exec-who-will-15919346.php |title=Who is Andy Jassy, the Amazon exec who will replace Jeff Bezos as CEO?|first=Susie|last=Neilson|date=February 2, 2021|website=San Francisco Chronicle |archive-url=https://archive.today/20210223074147/https://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/Who-is-Andy-Jassy-the-Amazon-exec-who-will-15919346.php |archive-date=23 February 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://therealdeal.com/la/2020/10/14/a-top-amazon-exec-buys-in-santa-monica/ |title=Amazon's Andy Jassy Buys Santa Monica Home|date=October 14, 2020|website=The Real Deal Los Angeles |archive-url=https://archive.today/20210204165502/https://therealdeal.com/la/2020/10/14/a-top-amazon-exec-buys-in-santa-monica/ |archive-date=4 February 2021}}</ref><ref name="auto3"/>

He is chairman of Rainier Prep, a [[Charter schools in the United States|charter school]] in Seattle.<ref>{{cite web |title=Board |url=http://www.rainierprep.org/board/ |access-date=October 12, 2017 |publisher=Rainier Prep}}</ref>
